names.en: Corporate Bank Account Opening (Business Manager Visa)
names.reading: ほうじん こうざ かいせつ もうしこみしょ

legal_basis.law: 犯罪による収益の移転防止に関する法律
legal_basis.law_en: Act on Prevention of Transfer of Criminal Proceeds (Anti-Money Laundering)
legal_basis.deadline_description_en: No legal deadline. In practice, you need a corporate account to transfer capital from your personal account after incorporation and to begin business transactions.
legal_basis.penalty_en: No penalty for delay, but operating without a corporate account creates accounting problems and reduces credibility with business partners.
legal_basis.cost_note_en: Free to open. Monthly fees vary — some banks charge ¥0, megabanks may charge ¥2,000-5,000/month for corporate accounts.

overview.difficulty_en: HIGH — Corporate account opening is one of the most difficult steps for foreign entrepreneurs in Japan. Banks reject applications frequently, especially from newly incorporated companies. Plan for 2-4 weeks of processing and possible rejection from your first-choice bank.
overview.timing_en: Open your corporate account AFTER company registration but BEFORE applying for (or renewing) your Business Manager visa, as immigration wants to see the capital properly transferred to a corporate account.
overview.strategy_en: Apply to multiple banks simultaneously. Start with Japan Post Bank or a regional/online bank (higher approval rate), then try megabanks later once you have transaction history.

business_manager_visa_context.capital_note_en: The capital must be deposited into your personal account first (as proof of funds during incorporation), then transferred to the corporate account after registration. Banks and immigration both want to see this paper trail.
business_manager_visa_context.employee_requirement: 2+ full-time employees (both capital AND employee requirements must be met since October 2025)
business_manager_visa_context.japanese_ability_note: JLPT N2 or equivalent required for at least the applicant or one full-time employee (since October 2025)
business_manager_visa_context.physical_office_note: Banks strongly prefer a dedicated physical office. Virtual offices and residential addresses are frequently rejected. Lease agreement will be requested.

bank_comparison_corporate.note: Most accessible for new companies. Does NOT allow business-purpose accounts for some entity types. Check eligibility first.
Online bank popular with startups. Fast application, lower rejection rate than megabanks.

bank_comparison_corporate.english_support: Some English-speaking staff at large branches
bank_comparison_corporate.note: Often recommended as the 'most realistic' megabank for foreign-owned companies. Having SMBC Prestia personal account may help.
Highest credibility if approved. Very strict with new/foreign companies. Often rejects on first attempt.

sections.note_en: The representative director must be a Japan resident. This is the person who signs the application.

fields.note_en: Should be 経営・管理 (Business Manager)

sections.note_en: Fill this section if the person who will operate the account daily is different from the representative director. For sole-director companies, this is usually the same person.
Required by anti-money laundering law. Declare anyone holding 25%+ of shares or voting rights.

fields.note_en: 普通預金 for general use; 当座預金 if you need to issue checks
Be specific: 事業資金の管理, 取引先への支払い, 売上の入金 etc.

sections.note_en: A dedicated banking seal (銀行印 ginkō-in) separate from your corporate registered seal (代表印 daihyō-in) is recommended. Using the same seal for both is a security risk.

fields.note_en: Corporate banking seal required — signatures alone are NOT accepted for corporate accounts

screening_tips.tip_en: Have a real website ready before applying
screening_tips.detail_en: Banks check your company website during screening. A professional site with your company name, services, contact info, and team page dramatically improves your chances. Even a simple one-page site helps.

screening_tips.tip_en: Physical office > virtual office > residential address
screening_tips.detail_en: Banks want to see your lease agreement. Virtual office addresses (バーチャルオフィス) are red flags. A small dedicated office or co-working membership with a fixed desk is much better.

screening_tips.tip_en: Bring a business plan in Japanese
screening_tips.detail_en: Even if the bank doesn't require it, having a well-written 事業計画書 in Japanese shows seriousness. Include: business description, target market, revenue model, 3-year projections, and how the account will be used.

screening_tips.tip_en: Apply to easier banks first, then upgrade
screening_tips.detail_en: Start with Japan Post Bank, GMO Aozora, or a regional bank (信用金庫). Once you have 6+ months of transaction history, megabanks become much more approachable.

screening_tips.tip_en: The representative director MUST be a Japan resident
screening_tips.detail_en: Non-resident directors almost always get rejected. If you haven't received your Business Manager visa yet, use a co-director who already has residency.

screening_tips.tip_en: Dress professionally for the branch visit
screening_tips.detail_en: Corporate account opening often includes an in-person interview at the branch. Dress as you would for a business meeting. First impressions matter in Japanese business culture.

screening_tips.tip_en: Bring any existing contracts or client relationships
screening_tips.detail_en: Purchase orders, service agreements, or letters of intent from real companies prove your business is legitimate and operational — not a shell company.
When asked 利用目的, don't just say '事業用'. Explain: 'We receive payments from X clients, pay Y suppliers, and handle Z operational costs monthly.' Specificity builds trust.

after_submission.en: Screening period: 2-4 weeks. Bank may call you or your office for additional information.
Result notification by phone or mail. If rejected, you will usually NOT be told the specific reason.

after_submission.ja: 口座開設完了・通帳発行
after_submission.en: Account opened. Receive passbook at branch or by mail. Note your account number (口座番号).

after_submission.ja: 個人口座から資本金を法人口座へ振込
after_submission.en: Transfer the paid-in capital from your personal account to the corporate account. Keep the transfer receipt — immigration wants to see this.

after_submission.ja: インターネットバンキング設定
after_submission.en: Set up corporate online banking. Approval may take an additional 1-2 weeks. You'll receive a security token by mail.

after_submission.ja: 税務署・年金事務所に届出
after_submission.en: Notify the tax office and pension office of your corporate account details.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Going straight to a megabank as a brand new company
common_mistakes.fix_en: Megabanks reject most new foreign-owned companies. Start with Japan Post Bank, GMO Aozora, or a local credit union (信用金庫). Build transaction history first.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Using a virtual office as your registered address
common_mistakes.fix_en: Banks view virtual offices as a red flag for shell companies. Get a dedicated physical space, even a small one. Co-working spaces with fixed desks and lease agreements can work.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Not having a company website or any web presence
common_mistakes.fix_en: Banks will Google your company. A professional website proves legitimacy. Even a simple bilingual one-page site with your business description, team, and contact info helps enormously.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Using your registered seal (代表印) as your banking seal
common_mistakes.fix_en: Create a separate banking seal (銀行印). If your registered seal is compromised, your bank account is too. Most seal shops (はんこ屋) can make a set of corporate seals.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Applying before your company registration is complete
common_mistakes.fix_en: You cannot open a corporate account without your Certificate of Registered Matters (登記事項証明書). Wait until registration is complete, then get fresh copies (within 6 months).

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Not being able to explain your business clearly in Japanese
common_mistakes.fix_en: The branch interview will be in Japanese. If your Japanese isn't business-level, bring a trusted Japanese-speaking colleague or hire a professional interpreter for the appointment.
Rejection is normal, especially from megabanks. Apply to 2-3 banks simultaneously. If rejected, ask why, improve your materials, and try a different bank.

common_mistakes.mistake_en: Not transferring capital to corporate account promptly
common_mistakes.fix_en: Immigration wants to see capital in a corporate account (not sitting in your personal account). Transfer promptly after opening and keep the receipt as proof for visa renewal.

rejection_handling.explanation_en: Corporate account rejection is extremely common for foreign-owned companies. Banks are rarely required to give specific reasons. Common unstated reasons include:
common_reasons: Company too new (under 6 months since incorporation)
No visible business activity (no website, no clients, no contracts)
Representative director not a Japan resident
Business description too vague or inconsistent with Articles of Incorporation
Industry perceived as high-risk (crypto, money transfer, consulting with no clear clients)
Insufficient paid-in capital for the stated business scope
next_steps: Ask the bank for feedback (they may give hints even if not required to)
Strengthen your weak points and apply to a different bank
Consider a credit union (信用金庫) — they serve local businesses and may be more flexible
Build 3-6 months of real business activity, then reapply
Consult with a judicial scrivener (司法書士) or administrative scrivener (行政書士) who specializes in foreign business setup
